title: 114_s1600
content: The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Act. These civil remedies are exclusive and subject to the same rights and limitations as individuals under the Privacy Act. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Act. The Attorney General may designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it has appropriate privacy protections or if determined necessary for preventing criminal offenses. The Attorney General can designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if it shares information with the US to prevent criminal offenses and has privacy protections. The designation can be revoked if the country fails to comply with the agreement or no longer meets the requirements. The Attorney General determines designated Federal agencies for information exchange with covered countries to prevent unlawful activity. The Department of Justice or its components require concurrence for designation. The Attorney General designates Federal agencies for information exchange with covered countries to prevent unlawful activity. Determinations made under this Act are published in the Federal Register and are not subject to judicial or administrative review. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia has exclusive jurisdiction over any claims arising under this section. The term "agency" is defined as in section 552(f) of title 5, United States Code. The term "covered country" refers to a country or organization designated under subsection (d). A "covered person" is a non-individual citizen of a covered country. A "covered record" is a record transferred to a designated Federal agency for criminal investigation purposes. The term "individual" is defined in section 552a(a)(2) of title 5, United States Code. This Act does not waive privileges or require disclosure of classified information. The Act will take effect 90 days after enactment.
